issues.description: Constructor signature for StockIngredient is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement's class diagram (and the solution implementation) expect a constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int). However, the template repository only provides a constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean). Students following the problem text or the example usage in Main (which instantiates StockIngredient with three arguments) will attempt to call the 3-argument constructor (e.g., new StockIngredient("Bacon", 10, 50)) and get a compilation error because that constructor is missing in the template. This blocks implementing SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery (and the example usages in Main) which constructs new StockIngredient objects with three parameters.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a 3-argument constructor StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) in the template (or an overload that delegates to the existing 4-argument constructor). For example: public StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) { this(name, price, quantity, false); } This matches the problem statement and the solution, and allows student code (and the example in Main) to compile and work as intended.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the provided UML) expects a StockIngredient constructor with signature StockIngredient(String, int, int). The solution implements exactly that constructor. However, the template repository's StockIngredient class only exposes a constructor with an additional boolean parameter (StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean strictValidation)). This mismatch means students following the problem instructions (or using the solution as reference) will expect to instantiate StockIngredient with three arguments, but the template API requires four. This creates a blocking mapping/confusion: students may attempt to call new StockIngredient(name, price, quantity) when implementing SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery and encounter compile errors or be unsure which constructor to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template API with the problem statement and solution by providing a StockIngredient constructor that matches StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity). Add an overloaded three-parameter constructor to the template (or replace the four-parameter one) so students can create StockIngredient instances as described in the UML. For example, add public StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) { this(name, price, quantity, /*defaultStrict=*/false); } or change the template constructor signature to the three-argument form.
